qas.question: What water source feeds the CAP?
What aquifer is Tucson starting new wells in?
How many wells has Tucson stopped using since 2001?

context: To prevent further loss of groundwater, Tucson has been involved in water conservation and groundwater preservation efforts, shifting away from its reliance on a series of Tucson area wells in favor of conservation, consumption-based pricing for residential and commercial water use, and new wells in the more sustainable <a3_0>Avra Valley aquifer<a3_0/>, northwest of the city. An allocation from the <a0_0>Central Arizona Project Aqueduct<a0_0/> (CAP), which passes <a1_0>more than 300 mi (480 km)<a1_0/> across the desert from the <a2_0>Colorado River<a2_0/>, has been incorporated into the city's water supply, annually providing over 20 million gallons of "recharged" water which is pumped into the ground to replenish water pumped out. Since 2001, CAP water has allowed the city to remove or turn off <a4_0>over 80<a4_0/> wells.
